review.title: An Efficient Triplet-based Algorithm for Evidential Reasoning
review.abstract: Linear-time computational techniques have been developed for combining evidence which is available on a number of contending hypotheses. They offer a means of making the computation-intensive calculations involved more efficient in certain circumstances. Unfortunately, they restrict the orthogonal sum of evidential functions to the dichotomous structure applies only to elements and their complements. In this paper, we present a novel evidence structure in terms of a triplet and a set of algorithms for evidential reasoning. The merit of this structure is that it divides a set of evidence into three subsets, distinguishing trivial evidential elements from important ones focusing some particular elements. It avoids the deficits of the dichotomous structure in representing the preference of evidence and estimating the basic probability assignment of evidence. We have established a formalism for this structure and the general formulae for combining pieces of evidence in the form of the triplet, which have been theoretically justified.

metadata.title: An Efficient Triplet-based Algorithm for Evidential Reasoning

sections.text: Linear computational techniques have been developed to combine evidence available for a number of debatable hypotheses, providing a means of making computationally-intensive calculations more efficient under certain circumstances. Unfortunately, they limit the orthogonal sum of evidence functions to the dichotomous structure - which refers only to elements and their complements. In this paper, we present a new evidence structure in the form of a triplet and a set of evidence algorithms. The merit of this structure is that it divides a set of proofs into three subgroups and distinguishes trivial proofing elements from important ones - focusing on some specific elements. It avoids the shortcomings of the dichotomous structure in representing the preference for evidence and estimating the basic probability assignment of evidence. We have established a formalism for this structure and the general formulas for combining proofs in the form of the triplet, which are theoretically and empirically justified.

sections.heading: 5 EVALUATION
sections.text: To perform a comparative analysis of the composition of dichotomous functions and the combination of triplet functions in terms of efficiency and accuracy, we implemented a series of algorithms to combine the two types of mass functions: dichotomous mass functions and triplet mass functions. We first divided the data into a group of testers with a 70% -30% share and then used our coarse learning algorithms to generate ten classification models.

sections.heading: 6 SUMMARY
sections.text: We have provided a theoretical basis for validating our triplet structure and formulas to substantiate the evidence, and have provided the general approximate formulas for combining evidence functions with the triplet structure. These formulas provide theoretical evidence that the temporal complexity of computing triplets can be achieved in linear time, and a basis for implementing the triplet algorithms. Furthermore, we have performed a comparative analysis to demonstrate the advantage of the triplet structure over dichotony in terms of measuring the basic probability mapping and efficiency in determining final decisions.
